Experience Business Development Manager, IoT/IoE Vertical and Solutions Group Cisco June 2015  – Present (3 months) London, United Kingdom Head of Business Development for Connected Lighting in EMEAR Business Development Manager - Innovation & IoE Cisco December 2012  –  June 2015  (2 years 7 months) London, United Kingdom I am currently focused on the key mega trend, Internet of Everything, which extends the widely known Internet of Things concept. Specifically my responsibility includes the creation of tangible use cases and developing an innovation ecosystem which is comprised of customers, traditional and non-traditional Cisco partners, early stage start-ups, and Industry boards. 
 
I am also the Operational Lead for the National Virtual Incubator (NVI) Alliance and a member of the Governing Board. The NVI is an alliance of universities/academia, research and science parks, local government partnerships, and innovation centres focused nurturing and developing entrepreneurship in the UK. (www.nvinetwork.com) 
 
Previously I was the Cisco lead for IDEALondon (a partnership with University College London and DC Thomson), where I was on the Operational Board and Governing Board. IDEALondon is an innovation and incubation centre which has been jointly created with UCL and DC Thomson. I was part of the founding team which developed the centre from concept to launch. (www.idea-london.co.uk) 
 
In parallel to the above, I am part of the core team which has developed Cisco UK&I's headline innovation programme, known as the British Innovation Gateway (BIG). This is a key strategic initiative which was created during our sponsorship of the London 2012 Olympic & Paralympic Games. Sales Business Development Manager - London 2012 Cisco Systems July 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 6 months) London, United Kingdom Co-led the business development of all London 2012 related and adjacent business opportunities stemming from sponsorship of London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games. My responsibilities included customer engagements through executive briefings, close partnering with senior management from the London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games (LOCOG), development of case studies and sales enablement collateral, and evangelising at industry conferences. 
 
Post Games responsibilities included the creation of a strategy to address the Physical Legacy (equipment resale) through a sales programme and brokering strategic deals for community projects aligning to the overall Legacy of skills, learning, and innovation. Technical Account Manager / Sales Engineer Cisco January 2008  –  July 2011  (3 years 7 months) London, United Kingdom Technical account manager/pre-sales engineer assigned to named accounts in the Financial Sector and Mobile Service Provider accounts. Specialised in Core & Edge, Finance (enterprise), and Mobile service providers. 
 
I was responsible for the technical sales for a key strategic EMEAR mobile service provider, and then transitioned into a UK role focused on top tier UK financial accounts, where I developed trusted relationships with key technical stakeholders and senior management. Network Consulting Engineer Cisco April 2006  –  January 2008  (1 year 10 months) Reading, United Kingdom I worked as a technical consultant as part of the Advanced Services (Professional Services) division focused on Mobile and Service Provider Accounts in the UK& Ireland. In this role my responsibilities included: consultancy in design & operational processes, software life-cycle management, design reviews, software management reviews, informal training, configuration best practices, and testing support. Summary I have spent over 25 years in Bio Tech and High Tech working in product, sales and marketing for both large and small companies. 
 
Today I enjoy being a part of the great Worldwide Partner Organization team at Cisco. 
 
In that role I work with Cisco sales, product development and partner teams to drive the Enterprise Networking go-to-market strategy for Cisco's channel partners, 
 
I specialize in: 
* Identifying the key results that need to be delivered  
* Bringing together the needed resources 
* Team-building, leadership, clear communication 
* Building a well-though out plan 
* Driving to completion 
 
I would describe myself as a "non-practicing geek" - Today I focus more on soft people-skills than hard technical knowledge. Learning technology is easy, getting a project successfully completed is much more difficult and certainly more interesting.  
 
I can see both the big picture as well as the granular details and understand that they both are important when it comes to success. Failure to clearly see both can be painful. Summary Filippo Galimberti has several years of experience the context of Service Providers. 
 
Currently at Cisco, as Business Development Manager, he's focusing on Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network function Virtualization (NfV) for EMEA Service Providers teams. 
 
 
Filippo focus in developing business through innovation of SDN and NfV, supporting SPs evolution Carrier WAN on innovation and Operations toward agility and optimization through SDN. 
 
He is also collaborating with the Cisco Engineering Department to develop the next generation of Cisco products and strategy. 
 
He has MsC degree in Electric Engineering. Before joining Cisco he has been working with major European Service Providers designing Software Architectures and Network Operations.
